content.title: MR Angiography (MRA)
content.definition: Non-invasive magnetic resonance imaging technique for vascular visualization using gadolinium contrast (CE-MRA) or flow-sensitive sequences (non-contrast MRA). Excellent soft tissue contrast with no ionizing radiation, making it valuable for renal patients and young individuals.

key_concepts.description: Gadolinium-based contrast injection with timed T1-weighted imaging; similar principle to CTA; excellent signal-to-noise; timing critical for arterial phase
Time-of-flight (TOF), phase-contrast, steady-state free precession (SSFP), quiescent-interval single-shot (QISS); avoid gadolinium in renal impairment or pregnancy
Flow-based technique; incoming blood appears bright against suppressed stationary tissue; no contrast needed; best for intracranial and carotid arteries
No ionizing radiation; no iodinated contrast (renal-safe with non-contrast techniques); excellent soft tissue contrast; no calcium artifact
Longer acquisition time; motion artifact susceptibility; claustrophobia; contraindicated with certain implants/pacemakers; overestimates stenosis (signal void); expensive
Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) risk in severe renal impairment (eGFR <30); use group II agents (lower risk) or non-contrast techniques; gadolinium deposition concerns in brain
Evaluates stenosis, plaque morphology, intraplaque hemorrhage (T1-weighted sequences); good alternative to CTA; may overestimate stenosis
Lower extremity runoff for PAD; particularly useful when renal function impaired; bolus-chase or time-resolved techniques
Excellent for chronic aortic disease, connective tissue disorders (Marfan), coarctation; 4D flow for hemodynamics; not for acute aortic syndrome (CTA faster)
Quantifies flow velocity and direction; useful for portal hypertension, shunts, valve quantification; can assess functional significance of stenosis

learning_objectives: Understand contrast-enhanced vs non-contrast MRA techniques
Know advantages over CTA (no radiation, no iodine, no calcium artifact)
Recognize gadolinium concerns in renal impairment (NSF)
Apply MRA appropriately based on clinical scenario
clinical_pearls: No radiation - good for young patients and surveillance
Use non-contrast techniques if eGFR <30 (NSF risk with gadolinium)
TOF MRA good for carotids without contrast
MRA tends to overestimate stenosis (use with duplex correlation)
Not first choice for acute aortic syndrome (too slow)
Can see intraplaque hemorrhage in carotids (CTA cannot)
common_mistakes: Using gadolinium in severe renal impairment without considering NSF
Choosing MRA for acute emergency (too slow)
Over-relying on MRA stenosis measurements (tends to overestimate)
